title: Which is better: computer science or information technology? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. If you like it and can do well at it. The wording of your question is ambiguous - are you comparing IT with Computer Science, as two opposing courses of study? Or are you grouping them together as opposed to studying History or Classics? If you are asking whether you should study IT and Computer Science, my answer is YES. I had two careers and the one I spent most of my time on, Music, was wonderfully satisfying but I didn’t make enough money to have a family and all the other things people want to do when they work full time. When I was in my late 20s I took some courses in Data Processing at my local UC extension - UC Berkeley extension. After about 7 classes I got a job, and later had my own company which produced niche database software for Orchestras. Having learned how to design, build and implement database applications, I became a self-employed software engineer/programmer and worked for myself for the next 15 years. I paid myself well. I live near silicon valley so all my jobs were with companies here. I think it doesn’t really matter where you are located, because you can do work off-site in most cases. The heading for this question is “Computer Science Education/Studying” so I assume you are younger, maybe in college, and choosing a major or area of study. I don’t know what the alternatives are, but in my experience IT/CS is a very good way to make a living. Apparently there are a lot of jobs going unfilled in the US. I bet a lot of them are in tech areas.

There’s no doubt in your mind—you want to work in the exciting world of technology! And with the promising job growth and exciting earning potential, who could blame you? The average median salary for professionals in this industry is upwards of $75,000 annually, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS).* These positions are also projected to grow by an average of nearly 19 percent through 2022, which is almost double the average growth rate of all occupations (11 percent). Considering all these factors, it’s easy to see why you’re interested in pursuing a degree in technology. The hard part is deciding which degree is right for you and your career aspirations. If you’re looking for a program that will prime you for success in a variety of technology careers, you’re probably considering IT versus computer science. The two may seem similar on the surface, but there are different skills and career opportunities associated with each.
